issuetype.description: A problem which impairs or prevents the functions of the product.
issuetype.name: Bug

resolution.description: All attempts at reproducing this issue failed, or not enough information was available to reproduce the issue. Reading the code produces no clues as to why this behavior would occur. If more information appears later, please reopen the issue.
resolution.name: Cannot Reproduce

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.
status.name: Resolved

fields.description: Running the azure test suites brought up some failures in {{TestFileSystemOperationExceptionHandling}}, related to timestamp being too far out. Looks like 30s off
fields.summary: azure TestFileSystemOperationExceptionHandling failing; object timestamps 30s out

comments.body:
{code}

This was fixed by playing with the NTP settings and getting the laptop's clock in order. 

However, do the tests need to worry so much about the client clock? I note that TestWasbUriAndConfiguration also failed when the time was out
{code}
Running org.apache.hadoop.fs.azure.TestWasbUriAndConfiguration
Tests run: 16, Failures: 0, Errors: 2, Skipped: 1, Time elapsed: 8.522 sec <<< FAILURE! - in org.apache.hadoop.fs.azure.TestWasbUriAndConfiguration
testConnectUsingSAS(org.apache.hadoop.fs.azure.TestWasbUriAndConfiguration)  Time elapsed: 1.718 sec  <<< ERROR!
org.apache.hadoop.fs.azure.AzureException: com.microsoft.azure.storage.StorageException: Server failed to authenticate the request. Make sure the value of Authorization header is formed correctly including the signature.

Is it that Azure is that fussy about client times?
Closing as cannot reproduce, leaving the stack traces here for searchability.
